[tye], 2002-06-28
Yes, I certainly have plans for the "wiki" links showing whether the wiki has been updated since you last "viewed"; it will if there is new content ;). I like the idea of making wiki updates easier. A chatterbox "/wiki pmdev ..." would be cool for very short updates. And a user-set "signature" that gets prepended when you "edit" would be cool except it needs to fill in the current date. I'd probably just hard-code prepending of "

[$USER->{title}], ".getYYYY_MM_DD()."
\n

\n" except that it squelches innovation. So we'd probably need a "wiki sig" and some template that gets replaced by the date. I'm prone to force YYYY-MM-DD format on people but my conscience gets the better of me so [strftime] would probably be used.

Of course, these would only prepend information at the top of the wiki (nothing else is practical, IMO). So I guess we have to call for "votes" on whether updates should be restricted to the tops or "scattered" (perhaps in archives, even??). I much prefer the "scan down until you recognize what was on top last time you read and then read the items going up" algorithm. I think I'd probably just mostly give up on reading the wiki if I had to scan the whole think looking for new stuff every time.

When we did the first wiki we voted on whether to append to the bottom or prepend to the top. I recall the "new stuff on top" having a clear "margin of victory".

BTW, (in case anyone is wondering) the way permissions on Everything work, to have nodes w/ replies that can only be seen by one group would require the creation of a section, a node type, and a new note type (which we've never done) for each group. This would require reworking much of the display code so it could handle multiple "note" types. So that large chunk of work was not done. And I'm not in favor of that anyway. I think if we have such a large discussion that threaded nodes are really required, then it is probably something that the community should be allowed to take part in as well.

Did you read [id://174416]? I just posted that I don't think the [Other Users] changes will be made. I came to this decision yesterday. I'm not hiding some master plan. (: If you are worried about making some major change that won't be used, then get some feedback before you start, of course.

Here are some things that need changing:

  1. You can approve your own nodes via each section's main page. It appears that my patch to disable this in the [approve] opcode got lost so I'll find that (found and applied now) but it'd be great if someone would add 'disable="disable"' to those checkboxes. Update: You can also approved reaped nodes this way. Only [editors] should be allowed to approve reaped nodes but the [approve] opcode doesn't enforce that. Perhaps a 'canapprove' htmlcode is in order.
  2. The [editors nodelet] should not allow a node to be moved if it is approved for its section. Editors should unapprove it for its section (and/or the frontpage, tho this is probably not required) and then move it (and reapprove it, if desired). We should test that leaving a node approved for the front page then moving it causes it to move to a different section on the front page (this takes a few minutes as the frontpage is cached).
  3. The [message] opcode should allow delete/archive/unarchive of messages that are to a group that you belong to (or any message if isGod($USER)).
  4. We'll need a way to edit messages in [message inbox] (such as an "edit" link for each message and/or a global "edit" checkbox that displays all archived messages in text boxes so you can edit several at once). To reduce (but no eliminate) race conditions, the actual update should check that the current text is the same as the starting text and refuse to update otherwise (probably with "update ... where message_id=? and msgtext=?" so SQL can perhaps completely remove the race condition).
  5. [Message inbox] should optionally show date/time of each message. I usually do this type of thing by first adding the option (check boxes: "[ ] Show date [ ] Show time") to [message inbox], then allowing something in $VARS to set the default, then updating [user settings] to allow setting the default.
  6. We should cache the chatterbox more effectively. I'd like the [message] opcode to call another htmlcode that inserts the record (I think it already does this; update: no, but moving this functionality from [message] opcode to [repeatedchatter] is nearly trivial) and have that (if not a /msg) also pre-HTMLize the record and add it to [cachedinfo] with code_id=[chatterbox], cachekey='HTML'.$message_id, and lastupdate=message.tstamp and have the code that [chatterbox] calls just read and concat these cached HTML records instead of rebuilding the HTML each page display. Similarly, add 'XML'.$message_id records and have the [chatterbox xml ticker] just read and concat those. A periodic process (such as [other users] nodelet) could delete old cached chatter.
  7. Once we have well-cached HTMLized chatter, we can host a [cblast35]-type node that has a more PM-like UI. I'd like to show only the minutes:seconds of the message timestamp (with a final "MM:SS of silence" note) and not put the message text into text areas.
  8. If you don't have the [approval nodelet], then it should automatically appear among the nodelets in it's "small" form which will have a title of "Node Status" and will show whether the node is considered, and who approved/frontpaged it. If it would be empty, then not even it's title will display.
  9. More likely to come...

My take on the query is that we don't really use 'title' so just select user_id from user and skip the node table entirely. Adding an index on "lasthere" in the user table might be a good idea and might not (probably not since we update that a ton and we'd be better off just querying it less often by having things like [other users xml ticker] use a cache similar to the way the [other users] nodelet works). kudra, 2002-06-06
I was recently making a number of suggestions to ar0n, and it got to the point that he recommended I make a list here to get other opinions (and probably to save himself some msgs). This is not to say that I'm not happy with the improvements to editor tools, such as ehomat and the 'edit' link in nre, but I still find myself repeating a lot of the same tasks several times daily and I think there's room for more automation, especially as the nodes that require editor assistance continue to increase.

  • An editor's version of ntc
    Right now, you have to click on a node in order to give it an editorial delete vote, or to unconsider it (assuming it doesn't have enough edit votes to show up in nre). I would like to see editorial delete and unconsider options that can be applied to a number of nodes at one time, much like the current ntc options. The delete would be useful for large numbers of blank nodes (there were at least 5 in ntc today), whereas the unconsider could be used for nodes which have too many keep votes to be deleted.
  • Automatic messaging box for unconsidered nodes
    I have recently started msging people when I unconsider their nodes due to a large number of keep votes. The message is generally: [id://1|a node you considered] has been unconsidered due to the number of keep votes. It should probably also contain a link to the consideration guidelines. I'd like the choice to send a message whenever I unconsider something (as I get with reparenting and editing).
  • Editor's signature
    I paste in the same few lines every time I edit a node. I'd like to see a default signature (either one written by each editor, or a generic one) in a seperate text box below the node I'm editing, with a checkbox (by default selected) to include the signature. Putting it in the textbox allows me to fill in the reason, and perhaps the date, although it would be much nicer if the date were automagically supplied. Having the checkbox allows me to leave out the signature, as I generally do when the author considered the node her/himself.
  • Multiple tasks in the same form
    Editing currently involves many, many reloads. I'd like to see some of the tasks combined in to the same form. For example, when editing a node, the 'submit' button could also include an unconsider checkbox, and a message to the node author (with a radio button to enable/disable sending it). In this instance the preview button would ignore everything other than the message text, regardless of its values. Another example is in ehomat: there could be an option to unconsider the child node and message the author of the child node on the same screen as 'does this look right?' (naturally ignored if you opt for no).
  • Anon authors excluded from default message sending
    If the author is anon, it would be nice not to have the default message displayed after editing. I usually catch myself, but sometimes I try to message anon when I've edited a node.
I do hope that some of these will be implemented, because it would really reduce the amount of work for editors. Right now I rarely spend less than 15 minutes a day editing, and I only see the time increasing :(
